column27: Shore of L. Rutanzige
column46: "The first stage, characterised by the Ishangian levels, is illustrative for a Late Pleistocene hunter-fisher-gatherer Community adapted to relatively dry and open savanna living conditions. For the moment it is impossible to give a more precise estimate of the age of the Ishango culture, but it is not inconceivable that the N.F.PR. assemblage relates to one of somewhat drier phases that occurred within the second half of the Late Pleistocene, i.e. from ca. 21000 to 17500 BP or from 14500 to 12500 BP."\r\nETE dating method: absolute, ETE age comment: "Max age = 21,000 +/- 500 (date in NFP at Is11). Min age = 6890 +/- 75 (charcoal from the Katwe ash)." radiometric intage_max, radiometric intage_min. Niveau fossilifere principal.

column27: 20km south of Liege, at the southwestern end of Sprimont commune. The site is on the right side of the River Ambleve south of Fraiture, approx. 2km from the confluence of the Ambleve and the Ourthe rivers near Comblain-au-Pont.
column46: "the cave appears in cross-section in the upper face of the Quarry called La Belle-Roche". Six levels identfied within the cave deposits, two of which contain faunal remains - 3 "Unsorted silty detrital complex" and 4 "Clay-calcite run-off complex". Four galleries have been found, only Gallery one lacks fauna and archaeology. Dated later than the Brunhes/Matuyama boundary (0.78Ma) and before 0.35Ma (the limit of Uranium/Thorium dating). Thought to be c.0.5Ma on faunal grounds. OIS stage 13 to (perhaps)15.
column47: Level 3 : "silty but progressively loaded from bottom to top wuith reddish decalcification clay and limestone rock fragments". Occasional reworked concretions, probably a secondary mud flow deposits. Bones found from bottom to top, rarely in anatomical position.\r\nLevel 4: "a complex of very thin interbedded layers of calcite, clay and clayey silt as well as a variable succession of laminar calcitic deposits and clayey run-off deposits" Lower layers contain lenses of microfauna, particularly Chiroptera. Higher levels are sterile. Laid down in a very humid period.
column58: Level 3 : "silty but progressively loaded from bottom to top wuith reddish decalcification clay and limestone rock fragments". Occasional reworked concretions, probably a secondary mud flow deposits. Bones found from bottom to top, rarely in anatomical position.\r\nLevel 4: "a complex of very thin interbedded layers of calcite, clay and clayey silt as well as a variable succession of laminar calcitic deposits and clayey run-off deposits" Lower layers contain lenses of microfauna, particularly Chiroptera. Higher levels are sterile. Laid down in a very humid period.

column46: hominid from the Intermediate Complex, all others from both the Intermediate Complex and the Lower Breccia. Dating done with Uranium series, and thermoluminescence yield dates 200-180kyr
column47: Intermediate Complex are transitional between sand/gravel units and breccia units. Unit is characterized by the presence of siliceous pebbles, badly sorted coarse sand and highly altered limestone clasts.\r\nBreccia units comprise many angular coarse particles, mainly limestone, with medium to strong carbonate cement.
column58: Intermediate Complex are transitional between sand/gravel units and breccia units. column27: Co-ordinates based on the city of Angouleme, the site is 20km North East of the city on a tributary of the Charente called the Tardoire.
column46: There are five members at this site ranging in age from the Middle to Upper Pleistocene. Members 1-3 (beds I-V) are Middle Pleistocene levels (estimated at 0.7-0.5Ma = 'Mindel-Riss' or 'Riss'), The Upper Pleistocene is represented by Members 4-5 (beds 5-10). The macromammal fauna is subdivided into groups 1-3 and these are entered here.

Suggested date for bed 10 is OIS 5d, temperate phase.

column46: Dated by ESR between 980,000 to 910,000 years ago (Jaramillo event). Late Early Pleistocene. Mammalian fauna is found in level 3, known as the 'Faunal horizon of Vallonnet'. There are three levels within member 3 - B1, B2 and C, but the large mammal faunal list is not subdivided.

column71: 5 stratigraphic units at the site. Bed 3 is further subdivided into levels B1, B2 and C, but the large mammal fauna is given as a list for the entire bed. The first level (C) correponds to a very dry and cold climate, whilst the upper (B1) is progressively more temperate and humid.

Coordinates based on information on the website of the UF Museum\r\n\r\nThe site is located within the boundaries of the Monkey Jungle zoological park in the southern Miami metropolitan area, Dade County, Florida. 25.57Âº N; 80.43Âº W.
column46: Morgan 2002: The fossils were discovered in a small sinkhole less than 5 m above sea level and approximately 10 km inland from the Atlantic Ocean on the Atlantic Coastal Ridge. Like Cutler Hammock, the fossils at Monkey Jungle were found in a sink-hole in a tropical hardwood hammock developed in the marine late Pleistocene Miami Limestone. Both the Monkey Jungle and Cutler sites were formed during periods of much lower sea level and correspondingly lowered water tables. Consequently, a very late Pleistocene (late Rancholabrean) age is most likely.
